entry.title: Shrine of Saint Lachtin's Arm (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that because the hand in the Shrine of Saint Lachtin's Arm (pictured) is clenched rather than open, it is assumed to have functioned as a battle standard or a talisman?

entry.title: Hugh III of Cyprus (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that when King Hugh III of Cyprus tried to force a marriage on his vassal, Lady Isabella of Beirut, the Egyptian sultan Baibars declared himself her protector?

entry.title: Queen of Peace Cemetery (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Queen of Peace Cemetery opened early because Cemetery of the Holy Rood filled up due to the COVID-19 pandemic?

entry.title: Robert Marquis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that architect Robert Marquis believed that architecture should meet "the users' spiritual and psychological needs" in addition to being functional?

entry.title: Shenlou zhi (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Qing-dynasty erotic novel Shenlou zhi has been called "the earliest novel by far" to describe the opium trade in China?

entry.title: Scott Lee Kimball (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Scott Lee Kimball killed three of his four known victims while he was working as an FBI informant?

entry.title: Listen, the Snow Is Falling (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Yoko Ono considered her 1971 song "Listen, the Snow Is Falling" to be the first pop song she ever wrote?

entry.title: Dietrich Roache (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Australian rugby sevens player Dietrich Roache kept the Australian national sprint champion out of the Australian Olympic team with his speed?
